focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 5 from both sides: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Divide by 2: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable term first by performing inverse operations on the constant term.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels <math><mn>300</mn></math> miles in <math><mn>5</mn></math> hours at a constant speed. What is the speed of the car in miles per hour?
questions.explanation: Speed is distance divided by time. <math><mfrac><mn>300</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> miles per hour.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the formula: Rate = Distance / Time.

questions.question: A circle in the <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane is defined by the equation <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. What is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: The standard equation of a circle is <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Here <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, so the radius <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>49</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In the circle equation, the number on the right side is the radius squared, not the radius itself.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mn>4</mn></math> for <math><mi>x</mi></math>: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>29</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Follow the order of operations: square the input first, then multiply by the coefficient, then subtract.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: The system of equations <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math> is graphed in the <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane. What is the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-coordinate of the intersection point?
questions.explanation: Set the equations equal: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Add <math><mi>x</mi></math> to both sides: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Subtract 1: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Divide by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='0' x2='200' y2='300' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='160' y1='210' x2='260' y2='10' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='-30' x2='360' y2='170' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='240' cy='50' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='250' y='50' font-size='12'>(2, 5)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Graph of two intersecting lines. The line y=2x+1 (blue) has a positive slope and the line y=-x+7 (red) has a negative slope. They intersect at the point (2, 5).
questions.score_improvement_tip: When both equations are solved for y, set them equal to each other to solve for x immediately.

questions.question: A bag contains <math><mn>10</mn></math> red marbles and <math><mn>15</mn></math> blue marbles. If one marble is selected at random, what is the probability that it is blue?
questions.explanation: Total marbles = <math><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Probability of blue = <math><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>25</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Probability is the number of favorable outcomes divided by the total number of possible outcomes.

questions.question: What is the sum of the solutions to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Sum is <math><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Alternatively, use <math><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mn>1</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic equation ax^2 + bx + c = 0, the sum of the roots is always -b/a.

questions.question: An angle has a measure of <math><mn>480</mn></math> degrees. What is the measure of the angle in radians?
questions.explanation: Multiply degrees by <math><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>180</mn></mfrac></math>: <math><mn>480</mn><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>180</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>48</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>18</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>8</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To convert degrees to radians, multiply by π/180. Simplify the resulting fraction.

questions.question: A student has a budget of <math><mi>$</mi><mn>500</mn></math> for a project. They have already spent <math><mi>$</mi><mn>200</mn></math> on supplies. The remaining supplies cost <math><mi>$</mi><mn>15</mn></math> per unit. Which inequality represents the maximum number of units, <math><mi>x</mi></math>, the student can purchase?
questions.explanation: The total cost is the initial <math><mn>200</mn></math> plus <math><mn>15</mn></math> times the number of units <math><mi>x</mi></math>. This total must be less than or equal to the budget of <math><mn>500</mn></math>. So, <math><mn>15</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>200</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>500</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate the word problem directly into math: 'per' usually means multiplication, and 'budget' or 'maximum' implies less than or equal to.

questions.question: If <math><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Recognize that <math><mn>32</mn></math> is a power of <math><mn>2</mn></math>. <math><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>1</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>,</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>. Therefore, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the first few powers of small integers (2, 3, 4, 5) to solve exponential equations quickly.

questions.question: What is the solution to the system of equations <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msqrt></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>y</mi></math>: <math><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Square both sides: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Simplify: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Possible solutions: <math><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Check <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: <math><msqrt><mn>4</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> but <math><mn>0</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> (Extraneous). Check <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>: <math><msqrt><mn>9</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mn>5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> (Valid).
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check for extraneous solutions when solving equations involving square roots by plugging the answers back into the original equation.

questions.question: The equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> defines a circle in the <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane. What is the diameter of this circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square for <math><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>y</mi></math>. <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. This gives <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. The radius squared is <math><mn>25</mn></math>, so <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The diameter is <math><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To convert a circle equation to standard form, complete the square for both variables. Don't forget to add the constants to both sides of the equation.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A poll of <math><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></math> likely voters shows that <math><mn>52</mn><mo>%</mo></math> support Candidate A, with a margin of error of <math><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math> at a <math><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></math> confidence level. Which of the following is the best interpretation of these results?

options.A: Candidate A will definitely win the election.
options.B: We are 95% confident that the true proportion of voters supporting Candidate A is between 49% and 55%.
options.C: There is a 3% chance that Candidate A will not receive 52% of the vote.
options.D: Exactly 52% of the population supports Candidate A.

questions.explanation: The margin of error creates an interval around the sample proportion. <math><mn>52</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math> is <math><mn>49</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>55</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. The confidence level indicates how sure we are that the true population parameter lies within this interval.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Margin of error describes the range of likely values for the population parameter, not the certainty of a single outcome.

questions.question: In the equation <math><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, <math><mi>a</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants. If the equation has infinitely many solutions for <math><mi>x</mi></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a linear equation to have infinitely many solutions, the variable terms must be identical and the constant terms must be identical on both sides. Thus, <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If an equation is true for all values of x (infinitely many solutions), the left side must be mathematically identical to the right side.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='350' viewBox='0 0 400 350' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='350' fill='white'/><defs><pattern id='grid' width='30' height='30' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse'><path d='M 30 0 L 0 0 0 30' fill='none' stroke='lightgray' stroke-width='0.5'/></pattern></defs><rect width='400' height='350' fill='url(#grid)'/><line x1='100' y1='0' x2='100' y2='350' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='385' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>x</text><text x='85' y='15' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>y</text><text x='85' y='165' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><circle cx='160' cy='240' r='150' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' opacity='0.6'/><line x1='160' y1='240' x2='250' y2='120' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><line x1='130' y1='30' x2='370' y2='210' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='160' cy='240' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='140' y='260' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>C(2, -3)</text><circle cx='250' cy='120' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='260' y='115' font-size='12' font-weight='bold'>P(5, 1)</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle graphed in the xy-plane with its center C at (2, -3). A radius is drawn from C to point P(5, 1) on the circle. A red tangent line passes through P.
questions.question: A circle in the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane has its center at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. A line is tangent to this circle at the point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the slope of this tangent line?
questions.explanation: First, find the slope of the radius connecting the center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math> to the point of tangency <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. The slope formula is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math>. Substituting the points: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>radius</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. The tangent line is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact. The slope of the tangent line is the negative reciprocal of the radius slope: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>tangent</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='350' viewBox='0 0 400 350' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='350' fill='white'/><line x1='100' y1='0' x2='100' y2='350' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='0' y1='150' x2='400' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='160' y1='240' x2='250' y2='120' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><line x1='130' y1='30' x2='370' y2='210' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 238 129 L 229 141 L 241 132' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><circle cx='160' cy='240' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='130' y='255' font-size='12'>C(2, -3)</text><circle cx='250' cy='120' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='260' y='115' font-size='12'>P(5, 1)</text><path d='M 160 240 L 250 240 L 250 120' fill='none' stroke='blue' opacity='0.5'/><text x='205' y='255' font-size='12' fill='blue'>3</text><text x='255' y='180' font-size='12' fill='blue'>4</text><text x='180' y='200' font-size='12' fill='blue' transform='rotate(-53 180,200)'>Slope = 4/3</text><text x='300' y='150' font-size='12' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>Perpendicular Slope = -3/4</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart highlights the perpendicular relationship between the radius and the tangent line. A slope triangle on the radius shows a rise of 4 and a run of 3, corresponding to a slope of 4/3. The tangent line is shown perpendicular to the radius.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Tangent lines to a circle are always perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact. If the slope of the radius is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi></math>, the slope of the tangent line is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>m</mi></mfrac></math>.

questions.question: For all positive values of <math><mi>a</mi></math>, which of the following is equivalent to <math><mfrac><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>5</mn></msup><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>?
questions.explanation: Apply exponent rules: <math><mfrac><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>5</mn></msup><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>. Then multiply by <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>: <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When multiplying terms with the same base, add exponents. When dividing, subtract exponents.

questions.question: Circle A is defined by the equation <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Circle B is obtained by shifting Circle A <math><mn>4</mn></math> units to the right and <math><mn>1</mn></math> unit up. If the equation of Circle B is written as <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Center of A is <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Shifting right 4 and up 1 gives new center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Radius remains <math><mn>4</mn></math> (<math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>). New equation: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Expand: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Combine constants: <math><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. So <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply translations to the center coordinates (h, k) directly, then write the new standard equation and expand it.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The mean of a data set consisting of <math><mn>5</mn></math> numbers is <math><mn>20</mn></math>. When a sixth number is added to the data set, the mean increases to <math><mn>22</mn></math>. What is the value of the sixth number?
questions.explanation: Sum of first 5 numbers = <math><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math>. Sum of 6 numbers = <math><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>22</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>132</mn></math>. The sixth number is <math><mn>132</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Work with the sum of the data values when calculating changes in the mean.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math> is graphed in the <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane. What is the minimum value of <math><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: This is a parabola in vertex form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. Since <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> is positive, the parabola opens upward, and the minimum value is the <math><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate of the vertex, <math><mi>k</mi></math>. Here, the vertex is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, so the minimum value is <math><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In vertex form y=a(x-h)^2+k, the vertex is (h,k). If a>0, k is the minimum. If a<0, k is the maximum.

questions.question: What is the value of <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Simplify the angle by subtracting full rotations (<math><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></math> or <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>6</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>). <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>18</mn><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. <math><mn>6</mn><mi>π</mi></math> represents 3 full rotations, so the terminal side is at <math><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Subtract multiples of 2π to find the coterminal reference angle in the first rotation.
